title-group.article-title: Effectiveness of constraint-induced movement therapy on activity and participation after stroke: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

abstract.p: Objective: To examine the effect of constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy on activity and participation of patients with stroke (i.e. the effect of different treatment durations and frequency) by reviewing the results of randomized controlled trials.
Data sources: A systematic literature search was conducted in MEDLINE, CINAHL, EMBASE, PEDro, OTSeeker, CENTRAL and by manual search.

Review methods: Randomized controlled trials for patients over 18 years old with stroke and published in Finnish, Swedish, English or German were included. Studies were collected up to the first week in May 2011. The evidence was high, moderate, low or no evidence according to the quality of randomized controlled trial and the results of meta-analyses.

Results: Search resulted in 30 papers reporting constraint-induced movement therapy, including 27 randomized controlled trials published between 2001 and 2011. Constraint-induced movement therapy practice for 60–72 hours over two weeks produced better mobility (i.e. ability to carry, move and handle objects) with high evidence compared to control treatment. Constraint-induced movement therapy for 20–56 hours over two weeks, 30 hours over three weeks and 15–30 hours over 10 weeks improved mobility of the affected upper extremity. However, with self-care as an outcome measure, only 30 hours of constraint-induced movement therapy practice over three weeks demonstrated an improvement.

Conclusion: Constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy proved to be effective on affected hand mobility and to some extent self-care on the World Health Organization’s International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health activity and participation component, but further studies are needed to find out the optimal treatment protocols for constraint-induced movement therapy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Constraint-induced movement therapy involves intense, functionally oriented task practice with the paretic upper extremity along with restraint of the less affected upper extremity for 90% of waking hours.1–3 Originally the therapy was delivered for about 6 hours a day for two weeks, resulting in more than 60 hours of practice with a focus on use of the paretic hand in a real-world environment.1–3 Modified constraint-induced movement therapy includes reducing practice (e.g. ref.4) or increasing (e.g. ref. 5) time and intensity or practising without restraint.6

Previous systematic reviews of interventions for the paretic upper extremity of patients with stroke has shown the effectiveness of constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy, particularly on hand mobility (i.e. on ability to carry, move and handle objects with an affected upper extremity).7–15 To date, there is sparse knowledge regarding the optimal amount (duration and frequency) of constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy practice with limited quality randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Recent systematic constraint-induced movement therapy reviews defined two subgroups ranked by the amount of task practice (a subgroup of 30 hours of therapy or less and over 30 hours of task practice).14,15 Sirtori et al.14,15 calculated the amount of practice by multiplying the number of weeks by the number of sessions per week by the session duration in hours. In our analysis we ranked the treatment by both duration and frequency, recording the number of hours during the week and the number of weeks. Sirtori et al.14,15 divided subgroups according to anatomical region of restraint, constraint effect and time since stroke. We did not differentiate between hand or hand and arm restraint. All our analysed interventions included constraint plus shaping techniques, because we excluded forced-use therapy. This was because we disagree that forced-use therapy is closely related to constraint-induced movement therapy, because it is only the restraint use without practice (e.g. ref. 16).

Finally, there are no meta-analyses that have analysed the effectiveness of constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy according to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF)-defined activity and participation measures. The ICF components consist of body functions, body structures, activity and participation, and environmental factors.17 The activity and participation component has nine domains and further categories at different levels. In the present study, we have linked the outcome measures to these domains according to the international guidelines and previous other literature.18–21

The purpose of this study was to investigate the evidence regarding the amount of constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy practice on the activity and participation of patients with stroke. The evidence is based on meta-analyses according to four subgroups with different amounts of practice, content of the control group therapy and quality of RCTs.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The search strategy was originally performed separately for physiotherapy and occupational therapy interventions for stroke (Figure 1). The search results for physiotherapy and occupational therapy searches were combined and later updates were searched directly with special search terms concerning stroke, and constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy.

caption.p: Flow chart for literature search concerning constraint-induced movement therapy (CIMT) and modified constraint-induced movement therapy (mCIMT). RCT, randomized controlled trial; FUT, forced-use therapy.

sec.p: A systematic literature search was conducted in OVID MEDLINE, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), EMBASE, Physiotherapy Evidence Database (PEDro), Occupational Therapy Systematic Evaluation of Evidence (OTSeeker), Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and by manual search. Two information specialists performed the searches in these electronic databases in conjunction with the researchers. The full search strategies are available on request from the corresponding author, and the OVID MEDLINE search strategy is available as an example on the web (Appendix 1).

Forced-use therapy (i.e. only restraint use without practice) was not accepted as a modified constraint-induced movement therapy, and thus was not included in the analyses. Only RCTs for patients over 18 years old with stroke and published in Finnish, Swedish, English or German were included in the study. Exclusion criteria were non-randomized and controlled pre-experimental studies and protocols. Studies were collected up to the first week in May 2011. Bibliographies of constraint-induced movement therapy review articles, narrative reviews and abstracts published in conference proceedings were also evaluated for relevant publications. In addition, citation tracking of all constraint-induced movement therapy review article references was conducted. Inclusion of articles was based on agreement between the two independent reviewers (first by titles and abstracts SP&TS&JP and MPK&MK, then by full-text reports SP&MPK).

sec.title: Methodological quality
sec.p: Methodological quality or risk of bias was assessed based on individual trial characteristics using the criteria of van Tulder et al.22 The items concern internal validity related to selection bias, performance bias, attrition bias and detection bias. All 11 items were rated as ‘yes’, ‘no’ or ‘don’t know’. If item A was rated ‘don’t know’, a request was sent to the authors to clarify whether the method of randomization was adequate. If two requests were not answered, the study was accepted, but the method remained rated as ‘don’t know’. RCTs were considered as high-level, acceptable or poor depending on the yes-rated items and number of subjects (see Table 1 on-line).23 The methodological quality and content analysis were evaluated by two blinded and independent assessors (SP and MPK). Any disagreements were resolved by consensus between the reviewers and remaining disagreements were decided by a third reviewer. Interrater reliability for the methodological quality assessment was computed by kappa statistics, in which adequate is 0.40–0.74 and excellent ≥0.75.24

sec.title: Meta-analyses
sec.p: The meta-analyses were performed in subgroups according to the amount of constraint-induced movement therapy practice as follows: 1) 60–72 hours over two weeks, 2) 20–56 hours over two weeks, 3) 30 hours over three weeks, and 4) 15–30 hours over 10 weeks. We ranked the treatment by both duration and frequency, recording the number of hours during the week and the number of weeks, to help clinical decisions according to the evidence of studies published as constraint-induced movement therapy.

In addition, the meta-analyses were divided for 1) constraint-induced movement therapy intervention versus no treatment and 2) constraint-induced movement therapy intervention versus control treatment. If a study presented more than one measure for the same outcome domain according to the ICF (e.g. on mobility, the measure most frequently used across studies in analysis was included). Measures were linked to the ICF domains according to the international guidelines and previous other literature.18–21

In the meta-analyses, Cochrane Collaboration’s Review Manager 5.0.16 program was used to calculate pooled effect estimates for combinations of single-study effects. The inverse-variance fixed-effect method or the inverse-variance random-effects method was used. Fixed-effect meta-analysis assumes that the true effect estimate is the same for a subgroup of included studies and single studies are estimates for that effect. This assumption implies that the differences between study results are due solely to the play of chance (i.e. there is no statistical heterogeneity). Random-effect meta-analysis assumes that effects that are estimated are not identical in different studies but it follows some distribution. The centre of this distribution describes the average of the effects and its width the degree of heterogeneity. For continuous outcomes there were two summary statistics available: the mean difference and the standardized mean difference (i.e. the effect size). The mean difference was used when studies had outcomes in the same scale, and when outcomes were reported in different scales the standardized mean difference had to be used.

First, change values for outcomes and their standard deviations were used if they were available. Second, the final values were used. If neither were reported, a request was sent to authors requesting this information. If two requests were not answered the RCT was not taken into account in the meta-analyses. In studies where multiple comparisons had been done, for example two or more treatment groups versus a control group; control group participant number was divided among comparisons and Roman numbers were used for more than one comparison. Overall effect was tested at z-test, where null hypothesis is that there is no difference between an intervention group and a control group. Evidence was categorized into four levels (Table 2 on-line).25

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Altogether 30 papers including 27 RCTs published during 2001–2010 fulfilled the inclusion criteria and 18 papers26–42 were excluded (Figure 1). After contacting the authors, the method of randomization of three studies remained unclear (Appendix 2 on-line).1,6,65 Methodological quality of the included RCTs was generally good: mean 5.5 (SD 1.4) yes scores, range 3–8 (Table 1 on-line). In our quality assessment, kappa for interrater reliability was 0.85 (excellent, P < 0.001).

Eight RCTs reported constraint-induced movement therapy with shaping plus standard task training for 6 hours per day for two weeks (10 days), altogether 60–72 hours,1,43–49 (i.e. original amount of constraint-induced movement therapy training) (Table 2 on-line). One RCT reported modified constraint-induced movement therapy according to training without the restraint on the non-affected upper extremity.6 Twenty RCTs reported modified constraint-induced movement therapy according to decreased training amount.4,50–68 In one study modified constraint-induced movement therapy practice was delivered for 2 hours every day for two months, resulting in about 112 hours of practice.5 It differed from the other groups and it was not included in the meta-analyses alone. However, this acceptable-quality RCT reported no difference between modified constraint-induced movement therapy and clinically based neurodevelopmental treatment of the same intensity.

Altogether, 27 different outcome measures were reported (Appendix 3 on-line shows all activity and participation outcomes used). The most common measures were the Motor Activity Log,1 Action Research Arm Test69 and Wolf Motor Function Test.70 In addition, the Functional Independence Measure,71 Stroke Impact Scale Participation item72 and Barthel Index73 were used. The higher score denotes better function, except in the Stroke Impact Scale. In the Wolf Motor Function Test, the lower time denotes better function.

sec.title: Constraint-induced movement therapy for 60–72 hours over two weeks
sec.p: The evidence from two high-quality studies44,49 showed that constraint-induced movement therapy practised for 6 hours from 5 to 6 times a week for two weeks resulted in faster hand and arm use and better perceived use of hand in daily living activities compared to control treatment (Figures 2 and 3). In two studies45,47 data were not available for the meta-analyses and in five studies the quality was poor1,6 or the studies were subgroup analysis43,46,48 (Appendices 1 and 2 on-line).

SD, standard deviation; Total, number of patients; Weight, percentages refer to the value of the study in the meta-analysis according to the Total; Random, random effect meta-analysis (estimated effects are not identical in different studies but it follows some distribution); 95% CI, 95% confidence interval.

SD, standard deviation; Total, number of patients; Weight, percentages refer to the value of the study in the meta-analysis according to the Total; Random, random effect meta-analysis (estimated effects are not identical in different studies but it follows some distribution); 95% CI, 95% confidence interval.

sec.p: Our analysis showed moderate evidence based on one high-quality RCT (Figure 4) that there was no difference in self-care between this amount of constraint-induced movement therapy and the control treatment.44 However, taking into account the larger high-quality study,49 it may change the evidence of effectiveness on self-care in favour of constraint-induced movement therapy. No evidence was found concerning original constraint-induced movement therapy compared with no treatment because there was only one poor-quality RCT43 (Appendices 1 and 2 on-line). Patients in this constraint-induced movement therapy subgroup were mainly more than three months post stroke.

caption.p: Functional Independence Measure (FIM), FIM – upper extremity and Barthel Index (standard mean difference): constraint-induced movement therapy treatment vs. control treatment. SD, standard deviation; Total, number of patients; Weight, percentages refer to the value of the study in the meta-analysis according to the Total; Random, random effect meta-analysis (estimated effects are not identical in different studies but it follows some distribution); 95% CI, 95% confidence interval.

sec.title: Constraint-induced movement therapy for 20–56 hours over two weeks
sec.p: Based on three acceptable-quality RCTs,50,51,53 moderate evidence showed that modified constraint-induced movement therapy practice 2, 3, 4 or 4–6 hours 5–6 times a week for two weeks tends to enhance hand mobility (i.e. ability to carry, move and handle objects), compared to control treatment (Figure 5). Moderate evidence also showed, according to two acceptable-quality studies53,55 that this amount of constraint-induced movement therapy subgroup showed better perceived use of hand in daily living activities (Figure 3). Three studies were excluded from the analyses because of poor-quality evidence4,52,54 (Appendices 1 and 2 on-line).

caption.p: Action Research Arm Test (0–57 scores): (a) constraint-induced movement therapy treatment vs. control treatment. (b) constraint-induced movement therapy treatment vs. no treatment; SD, standard deviation; Total, number of patients; Weight, percentages refer to the value of the study in the meta-analysis according to the Total; Random, random effect meta-analysis (estimated effects are not identical in different studies but it follows some distribution); 95% CI, 95% confidence interval.

sec.p: Moderate evidence according to three acceptable-quality studies50,51,53 showed that this amount of constraint-induced movement therapy did not produce better outcomes on self-care compared to control treatment. Patients in this constraint-induced movement therapy subgroup were from different phases of stroke (Appendix 2 on-line).

sec.title: Constraint-induced movement therapy for 30 hours over three weeks
sec.p: Moderate evidence based on four acceptable-quality RCTs56–58,60 showed that modified constraint-induced movement therapy practice 2 hours every working day for three weeks enhanced perceived use of hand in daily living activities compared to control treatment (Figure 3). One study was excluded from the analyses because of the poor-quality evidence.59 In addition, this amount of constraint-induced movement therapy produced better outcomes on self-care compared to control treatment. This moderate evidence was based on three acceptable-quality RCTs57,58,62 (Figure 4).

For this level of modified constraint-induced movement therapy we analysed the Stroke Impact Scale Participation item. The low and inconsistent evidence of the participation was reported in three acceptable-quality RCTs57,58,61 with no differences between the modified constraint-induced movement therapy and the control treatment (Figure 6). In addition, in one study,61 the post-treatment mean Stroke Impact Scale Participation item value was better in the control group (54.3 vs. 40.9). However, there was no change in the control group whereas it was 10.8 in the modified constraint-induced movement therapy group. Unfortunately, we did not have the exact mean change plus SD values available in the meta-analyses instead of post-treatment values. In this amount of constraint-induced movement therapy subgroup, all patients were more than three months post stroke, and the mean time after stroke was more than six months post stroke.

caption.p: Stroke Impact Scale (SIS) – Participation (8–40 scores): constraint-induced movement therapy treatment vs. control treatment. SD, standard deviation; Total, number of patients; Weight, percentages refer to the value of the study in the meta-analysis according to the Total; Random, random effect meta-analysis (estimated effects are not identical in different studies but it follows some distribution); 95% CI, 95% confidence interval.

sec.title: Constraint-induced movement therapy for 15–30 hours over 10 weeks
sec.p: Low evidence showed based on one acceptable-quality RCT68 that modified constraint-induced movement therapy practice for 30 minutes to 1 hour three times a week for 10 weeks enhanced hand mobility compared to no or control treatment (Figure 5). In addition, one acceptable-quality study66 reported positive mobility outcomes, although data were not available for the meta-analysis. Also, we excluded four poor-quality RCTs61,63–65,67 from these analyses (Appendices 1 and 2 on-line). In this constraint-induced movement therapy subgroup, patients were more than six months post stroke.68

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our meta-analysis included 30 RCT reports regarding constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy. It was found that original constraint-induced movement therapy practiced for 6 hours 5–6 times a week for two weeks produced better Wolf Motor Function Test time and Motor Activity Log results and quality of hand use of compared to control treatment. These variables belong to the ICF Mobility domain in the activity and participation component and are concerned with the carrying, moving and handling of objects. All three analysed modified constraint-induced movement therapy levels are also appropriate for patients with stroke improving the mobility of the affected upper extremity (i.e. carrying, moving and handling objects with the affected upper extremity). Constraint-induced movement therapy practised for 2 hours every working day for three weeks produced better Functional Independence Measure scores compared to control treatment. This variable and the Barthel Index used in other constraint-induced movement therapy subgroups50,53 belongs to the ICF Self-care domain. In all other analysed constraint-induced movement therapy subgroups self-care did not show improvement compared to the other treatment. However, all elicited evidence was moderate and we need more high-quality RCTs to study the effects of constraint-induced movement therapy on self-care.

Very few studies had used the outcomes linked to the ICF participation. Only three studies had used the Stroke Impact Scale Participation item as an outcome measure. However, to identify a measure assessing the ICF concept of participation is to find out whether it includes a minimum of three domains from chapters 3–9 (Communication; Mobility; Self-care; Domestic life; Interpersonal interactions and relationships; Major life areas; and Community, social and civic life) in the activities and participation.74 We agree with this view; it is very difficult to differentiate properly between activity and participation.

The evidence varied from low to high depending on the level of constraint-induced movement therapy, outcome and control treatment. Several missing methodological issues influenced the quality of the studies analysed and therefore the level of evidence. The most important and too often poorly reported quality issue was randomization method and concealment of treatment allocation, which should be reported clearly in all RCTs. Intervention compliance was also typically poorly reported. In half of the studies the co-intervention use was unclear. Furthermore, as expected, patients could not be blinded for the constraint-induced movement therapy, except in one RCT,57 and therapists were not blinded for the interventions in any of the analysed RCTs. It is obvious in this type of intervention study that blinding cannot be preformed when there is an interaction between a therapist and a client. Moreover, the statistical power was rather low in most of the studies since the number of patients was less than 30 in 12 studies. Importantly, to achieve high-quality studies, authors should follow consolidated standards while running and reporting RCTs in order to avoid the aforementioned missing quality issues.75,76 It is important to understand these key points of risk bias and to read reports of trials critically.

In the present study, the evidence was assessed against the ICF activity and participation component. In this component, the measures were linked to mobility and self-care. In the present study the highest level of constraint-induced movement therapy showed the strongest evidence on positive improvement of hand mobility. Our finding is in contrast to the recent systematic constraint-induced movement therapy review of 19 studies with two subgroups ranked by the amount of task practice.14 The meta-analysis of Sirtori et al. showed that a subgroup which received 30 hours or less constraint-induced movement therapy task practice produced a significant difference between the constraint-induced movement therapy group and the control group in upper limb function, however, over 30 hours of task practice produced no difference between the groups.14 However, Sirtori et al. updated their search with four new studies and then their updated meta-analysis no longer indicated a benefit of constraint-induced movement therapy, modified constraint-induced movement therapy or forced-use therapy on disability.15 The contradictory results of our findings may be explained at least partly by different calculations for the amount of therapy. Sirtori et al. calculated the amount of practice by multiplying the number of weeks by the number of sessions per week by the session duration in hours.14,15 In our analysis we ranked the treatment by both duration and frequency, recording the number of hours during the week and the number of weeks. This ranking is more consistent with clinical decisions. In addition, as we explained before, we did not include forced-use therapy studies and this also might explain different results.

This study has several strengths. First, our search was comprehensive, encompassing all the relevant databases, and second, we included only RCTs in our analyses. Third, we did accurate quality analyses for included RCTs taking into account risk of bias and number of subjects and resulting different levels of evidence. However, our meta-analysis had some limitations. Despite careful planning, all information needed for the meta-analyses was not available in all the studies despite requests from the authors. The Motor Activity Log test was handled as a continuous variable in some studies, although it originally has only five categories. The diverse content of the interventions in modified constraint-induced movement therapy made the analysis and conclusions complicated. As time since stroke onset varied greatly (Appendix 2 on-line), we were not able to use time following onset of stroke as a basis for subgroup analyses although that is an important factor in terms of stroke rehabilitation.

Recent studies in patients with stroke strongly suggest starting the interventions with specific, ambitious, relevant and time-limited goal-setting, with incremental steps that lead to progressive achievement in activity and participation.74,77 Despite the above noted limitations, our results can help clinical judgements to set goals for affected upper extremity therapy. Constraint-induced movement therapy and modified constraint-induced movement therapy proved to be effective on affected hand mobility and to some extent self-care in the ICF activity and participation measures, but further studies are needed to determine the optimal level of constraint-induced movement therapy and to elucidate concurrent therapy protocols.

list-item.p: Constraint-induced movement therapy, 6 hours every working day for two weeks had high evidence of benefit; less therapy gave less evidence of benefit.

Constraint-induced movement therapy benefit is in the Mobility domain in the ICF activity and participation component (i.e. in carrying, moving and handling objects with the affected upper extremity).
